cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: Without engine oil:
questions.answerA: A vehicle will get better gas mileage.
questions.answerB: An engine can be destroyed quickly.
questions.explanation: It is essential that a vehicle's engine have adequate oil pressure. An engine can be destroyed rapidly if it is run without oil.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping on the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brakes are controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. Pull the knob out to activate the parking brakes and push it in to release them.

questions.question: The two markings on a front brake limiting valve usually read:
questions.explanation: Some vehicles with air brake systems manufactured before 1975 have a front brake limiting valve with "normal" and "slippery" settings.

questions.question: Sending text messages while driving:
questions.answerA: May be done if the messages are short.
questions.answerC: Is permitted if you are asking a question of your employer.
questions.explanation: Sending and reading text messages while driving is prohibited.

questions.question: When taking the basic control skills test, drivers are:
questions.answerA: Not permitted to stop and exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerB: Encouraged not to exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerC: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in reverse.
questions.answerD: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in neutral and the parking brake is set.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, you must place the vehicle in neutral and set the parking brake before exiting the vehicle to check its position. You may check the position of the vehicle no more than twice, except during the straight line backing exercise, where you may look no more than once.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts should be:
questions.answerC: Inspected, but only about once a month.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check all belts for tightness and excessive wear.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: What is sleep debt?
questions.answerA: When you fall behind on sleep
questions.answerB: When you want to take a nap
questions.answerD: The amount of time it takes to get ready to drive after sleeping
questions.explanation: You can build up a "debt" of sleep if you do not sleep for adequate amounts of time. You can only catch up on the time that you "owe" by getting more sleep.

questions.question: A hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent a truck from rolling backwards when starting from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep the vehicle from rolling backwards when the vehicle is started from a stop.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: Overloading a vehicle with cargo:
questions.answerA: Usually has no effect on the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Can impact the vehicle's steering and brake control.
questions.answerC: Can impact the vehicle's electrical system.
questions.explanation: Overloading a vehicle can have negative effects on steering, braking, and speed control. Learn to recognize when cargo is overloaded or poorly balanced.

questions.question: When you need to stop in an emergency, you should:
questions.answerA: Lock the wheels and skid to a stop.
questions.answerB: Stop in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line.
questions.answerC: Stop in a way that turns your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Expect your vehicle to slow down more quickly than usual.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle traveling in a straight line while still allowing you to turn, if necessary.

questions.question: While driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Develop plans to get out of any dangerous situation that could arise.
questions.answerD: Focus on your own driving and not worry about other drivers.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should consistently check the road ahead for hazards. Develop a plan to deal with any hazards that could arise.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with power steering, the hoses should be checked:
questions.answerB: To ensure that they are still clear.
questions.answerC: To ensure that they are connected to the battery.
questions.answerD: To ensure that they contain the proper amount of play.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: Explosives are placed in hazardous materials Class 1.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is best to allow more room to open up in front of your vehicle. This will help you avoid the need for sudden stops, which could result in the tailgater rear-ending you, and will make it easier for the tailgater to pass. Speeding up may only make things more dangerous by prompting the other driver to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: When steering to avoid a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use one hand to steer.
questions.answerB: Keep both hands on the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Not use your mirrors to check other lanes.
questions.answerD: Speed up as you get nearer to the hazard.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid colliding with a hazard in the roadway, you should always keep both hands on the steering wheel. You must have a firm grip on the wheel to be able to turn quickly.

questions.question: To warn drivers behind you that you will be slowing down, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on the right turn signal followed by the left turn signal.
questions.answerB: Tap your brake pedal a few times to illuminate your brake lights.
questions.answerC: Swerve from side to side to get their attention.
questions.explanation: To let drivers behind you know that you plan to slow down, lightly tap your brake pedal a few times to flash your brake lights. It is important to communicate your intentions to other drivers.

questions.question: If a person operates in both excepted and non-excepted intrastate commerce, which type of license should the driver select?
questions.explanation: To operate in both excepted intrastate commerce and non-excepted intrastate commerce, you must choose a non-excepted intrastate commerce license.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: Manual air tank drains should be:
questions.answerA: Opened to drain the tanks after each day.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: When it’s difficult to see, such as at dawn or dusk, a driver can increase their vehicle's visibility by:
questions.explanation: When driving at dawn, at dusk, or in inclement weather, you should use your headlights on their low beam setting to increase your visibility.

questions.question: What should you do when confronted with an aggressive driver?
questions.answerB: Try to stay in the other driver’s way.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, the most important thing for you to do is get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact, do not challenge them by increasing your speed, and do not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they direct toward you.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Is not available for most trucks.
questions.answerB: Is not helpful in most situations.
questions.explanation: Beginning between 1997 and 1999, most commercial vehicles, trailers, and dollies are required to be equipped with ABS.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Tread of 3/32 of an inch in the grooves of the front tires
questions.explanation: When checking the tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, make sure the tires have sufficient tread. There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread in every major groove of the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on the other tires. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and figure out what's wrong.
questions.explanation: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should stop driving as soon as possible and try to figure out what is wrong. There could be an issue in your vehicle that could lead to engine failure and possibly a fire.

questions.question: The emergency brake system uses:
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system.
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system.
questions.answerC: Parts of both the parking and service brake systems.
questions.answerD: Only parts unique to the emergency brake system.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: When driving in the winter, which of the following should receive extra attention in a pre-trip inspection?
questions.explanation: When driving during the winter, it is especially important to make sure the coolant and antifreeze are at safe levels.

questions.question: If involved in an accident, which of the following is not recommended?
questions.answerA: Trying to move your vehicle to the side of the road
questions.explanation: When involved in an accident, you should protect the area, notify authorities, care for the injured, collect required information, and report the accident. You can lose your license for leaving the scene of an accident.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: The first hazardous materials class includes explosives such as ammunition, dynamite, and fireworks.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: If you must drive in fog, you should use your low beam headlights and fog lights, even during the daytime.

questions.question: Mirrors should be used:
questions.answerA: Only when there may be an emergency.
questions.answerC: By a helper to monitor your blind spots.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should frequently check the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle.

questions.question: When inspecting the exhaust system for defects, which of the following should be fixed?
questions.answerB: A broken exhaust pipe, muffler, or tailpipe
questions.explanation: Exhaust system defects can be extremely serious because they may make it possible for poisonous fumes to enter into the cab or sleeper berth. Issues to check for in a pre-trip inspection include loose, broken, or missing exhaust pipes, mufflers, tailpipes, vertical stacks, mounting brackets, clamps, bolts, or nuts; exhaust system parts that are rubbing against fuel system parts, tires, or other moving parts of the vehicle; and exhaust system parts that are leaking.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerA: Brake normally, as you will still have functioning brakes.
questions.answerC: Press the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: Without a working Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), your vehicle will still have normal brake function. Continue to drive and brake as you normally would and have your ABS serviced as soon as possible.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle, rough acceleration is:
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: If a vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. In what condition should the belt be?
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with air brakes that has a belt-driven air compressor, you should check the condition and tightness of the belt. It should be in good condition.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerA: Are not safe to be used.
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires on the rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used only when carrying a heavy load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs should never be used.

questions.question: Why are multi-speed axles and auxiliary transmissions used?
questions.answerA: To make a vehicle operate more smoothly
questions.answerC: To improve a vehicle's gas mileage
questions.explanation: On many vehicles, multi-speed rear axles and auxiliary transmissions are used to provide extra gears.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it may cause the wheels to lock.
questions.explanation: You should not brake while making a quick turn to avoid a hazard. Doing so could cause your wheels to lock and make your vehicle skid out of control.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When backing a truck, always use the mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Have someone help you whenever possible.

questions.question: Alcohol begins to affect the body:
questions.answerB: After several drinks have been consumed.
questions.explanation: Alcohol consumption impairs muscle coordination, reaction time, depth perception, vision, judgement, and inhibition. For some people, signs of impairment may begin with the first drink of alcohol. It is safest to not operate any motor vehicle after consuming alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: Improperly loaded cargo can:
questions.answerB: Hurt or kill the driver during a quick stop.
questions.answerC: Make it easier to stop a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Improperly secured or loaded cargo can be very dangerous. For example, loose cargo could fall in the event of a sudden stop, potentially injuring or even killing the driver.

questions.question: When driving under wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that:
questions.answerA: Ice has formed on the road.
questions.answerC: The spray is caught on the underside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: In wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that ice has formed on the road. Be especially cautious when traveling under wet conditions in freezing weather.

questions.question: When accelerating on a surface with poor traction, such as a wet road, a driver should:
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about the pavement.
questions.explanation: You should accelerate very gradually when driving under conditions that create poor traction.

questions.question: If you have more than one license:
questions.answerA: You are unlikely to be caught.
questions.answerD: There is no way for authorities to find out.
questions.explanation: A person may not have more than one license. Violation of this law may be punishable by jail time and/or a fine of up to $5,000.

questions.question: If stopped on the road or shoulder, within 10 minutes, you must:
questions.answerC: Stand behind your vehicle and motion for traffic to pass you.
questions.explanation: If stopped on the side of the road, you must place emergency warning devices, such as reflective warning triangles, within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: Tie-downs are used to:
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers, cargo must be secured by tie-downs to keep it from shifting or falling off while the vehicle is in motion. Tie-downs may also be used to prevent cargo shifting in closed vans. Shifting cargo could affect the handling of a vehicle.

questions.question: Hydraulic brakes can fail due to:
questions.answerC: Driving uphill for long periods of time.
questions.explanation: Failure of hydraulic brakes is often caused by a loss of hydraulic pressure. Hydraulic brakes may also fade because of overuse on a long downgrade.

questions.question: If equipped, a header board should:
questions.answerC: Be strong enough to contain cargo.
questions.answerD: Light up when the engine is started.
questions.explanation: When checking a header board during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that it is secure, free of damage, and strong enough to contain cargo.

questions.question: When starting the engine as part of the pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.explanation: Check your engine during the pre-trip inspection. After starting the engine, you should listen for unusual noises.

questions.question: When starting from a stop:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should shift to the right.
questions.answerB: A vehicle should be put into third gear.
questions.answerC: A vehicle should not roll back.
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting anything behind you, make sure that your vehicle does not roll back when you start from a complete stop.

questions.question: When you are driving while drowsy, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and try to finish the trip.
questions.explanation: The only effective way to deal with drowsiness while driving is to stop and sleep. Caffeine or other stimulant drugs may help you stay awake, but they will not keep you alert. You will likely end up being even more tired when the artificial stimulants begin to wear off.

questions.question: Mirrors should be:
questions.answerC: Checked only if there is a reason to suspect a problem.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should regularly check your mirrors, both to be aware of traffic and to check for problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: How much water needs to be on the surface of a road for a vehicle to hydroplane?
questions.answerB: A good amount, such as a large puddle
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be much water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: If you plan to transport hazardous materials, you must pass which endorsement test?
questions.explanation: You must have a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport defined classes of hazardous materials.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to use your mirrors?
questions.answerC: You are looking at fuel prices.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be part of your normal driving routine, checking your mirrors is especially important when turning, changing lanes, merging, and performing tight maneuvers.

questions.question: When checking windshield wiper blades, they should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check the wiper blades for damage, stiff rubber, and proper securement. Clean the blades if they are dirty.

questions.question: When operating a truck requiring a CDL:
questions.answerA: You are never required to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You must always wear a seat belt.
questions.answerD: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if you are driving a tank vehicle.
questions.explanation: A driver's seat should always be equipped with a seat belt. You must wear a seat belt at all times while operating a CMV.

questions.question: In cold weather, an alcohol evaporator should be checked and filled:
questions.explanation: An alcohol evaporator can help prevent ice from building up in an air brake system. In cold weather, the evaporator should be checked and refilled every day.

questions.question: Drowsy driving is most common during:
questions.explanation: Drowsy driving is most common during the night because people are naturally prone to be less alert in the hours during which they are normally asleep. If you must drive at night, take every precaution to prevent fatigued driving.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle, you should:
questions.explanation: You should always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: A serious traffic violation involves each of the following offenses, except:
questions.explanation: Traffic violations classified as "serious" include excessive speeding, reckless driving, operating a CMV without a valid CDL, following other vehicles too closely, and improper lane usage. Consequences for multiple serious traffic violations can result in license disqualification.

questions.question: If an applicant does not receive an air brakes endorsement:
questions.answerA: They cannot operate a vehicle with air brakes.
questions.answerB: They can only operate a vehicle with air brakes in intrastate commerce.
questions.answerC: They can only operate a vehicle with air brakes in interstate commerce.
questions.explanation: If you wish to be licensed to drive a CMV with air brakes, you must pass the air brakes knowledge test and use a vehicle with air brakes for your skills test.

questions.question: If you have an engine fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Open the hood as soon as possible.
questions.answerB: Turn off the engine as soon as possible.
questions.explanation: To keep an engine fire from spreading, you should turn off the vehicle's engine as soon as possible. Do not open the hood if you don't have to.

questions.question: When traveling on a downgrade, a vehicle will:
questions.answerB: Travel at the same rate as on level roadway.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the force of gravity will cause a vehicle to speed up. Adjust your speed before approaching a hill to reduce overuse of your brakes.

questions.question: An underloaded front axle:
questions.answerB: Is encouraged as front axles are usually less strong than other axles.
questions.answerC: Is discouraged as it can cause steering problems.
questions.answerD: Is discouraged as it can improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: Underloading a front axle may make it impossible to safely steer your vehicle. Keep weight distribution in mind when loading cargo.

questions.question: If your vehicle is equipped with a cargo lift, you should ensure that:
questions.answerD: The lift is the proper color.
questions.explanation: When checking a cargo lift as part of your vehicle inspection test, you should check for leaking, damaged, or missing parts. The lift must be fully retracted and latched securely.

questions.question: When approaching your vehicle, you should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The vehicle is shiner than others.
questions.answerB: The vehicle is not parked too closely to other vehicles.
questions.answerC: There are not puddles under the vehicle that indicate a leak.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle before an inspection, make note of its general condition and ensure that it is not damaged or leaning. Look under the vehicle for fresh leaks. Check around the vehicle for hazards to movement, such as people, other vehicles, or low-hanging wires or tree limbs.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade, the best way to use your brakes is to:
questions.answerA: Ride the brakes all the way down the hill.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes for a few seconds, then release the brakes for a few seconds. Continue to repeat these steps as you travel down the hill.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes only near the bottom of the downgrade.
questions.answerD: Apply consistent pressure to the brake pedal all the way down the hill.
questions.explanation: On a long or steep downgrade, brakes should only be used to supplement the braking effect of the engine. Apply the brakes just enough to feel a definite slowing down, then release them once you are about 5 mph below your target "safe" speed. Once your vehicle reaches its safe speed again, repeat this process.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, but have the brakes repaired within a week.
questions.answerB: Pull over and inspect the brakes.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should immediately bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes. Inspect and repair the brakes as soon as possible.

questions.question: If you are experiencing an engine fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Open the hood as soon as possible.
questions.explanation: In the event of an engine fire, you should turn off the engine as soon as possible. Do not open the hood unless absolutely necessary. Using a fire extinguisher, shoot foam through the louvers or radiator, or from the vehicle’s underside. If you are unsure of how to treat a fire, wait for firefighters to arrive.

questions.question: When traveling down a hill:
questions.answerD: You will slow to a stop.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle is traveling on a downward slope, the force of gravity will cause its speed to increase.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerA: Only occurs at extremely high speeds.
questions.answerB: Can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.
questions.answerC: Happens most frequently when tire pressure is too high.
questions.explanation: If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph. It is most likely if the tires' air pressure is too low or if tires' tread is worn.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher on a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close to the fire as possible.
questions.answerB: Stay as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answerC: Aim the extinguisher at the top of the flames.
questions.answerD: Aim the fire extinguisher at the ground about two feet away from the fire.
questions.explanation: When using a fire extinguisher, you should stay as far away from the flames as possible and aim at the base of the fire.

questions.question: If transporting livestock, drivers should be concerned about:
questions.answerB: The vehicle's weight shifting as the animals move.
questions.explanation: Because live animals can lean during curves, and otherwise move in transit, the weight distribution of a cargo of livestock is unstable. Driving with livestock requires special care.

questions.question: When stopping a manual transmission vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Push the clutch in when the engine is close to idle.
questions.answerB: Push the clutch out when the engine is close to idle.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when the engine is close to idle.
questions.explanation: When stopping, apply gradual pressure to the brake pedal and stop smoothly. If stopping a manual transmission vehicle, push the clutch in when the engine is close to idle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not required safety equipment?
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerB: Should be repaired, but not immediately.
questions.explanation: The suspension system performs the vital functions of holding up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in the suspension are therefore extremely dangerous.

questions.question: After starting the engine, the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) light stays on if:
questions.answerB: The ABS is not working properly.
questions.explanation: The Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) indicator light should come on after an engine is started. The light will then turn off. If the light remains on, the ABS it not working properly.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment, you should check all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The coolant level in the radiator.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine compartment, be sure to check the oil level; the radiator coolant level and the condition of the hoses; the power steering fluid level and the condition of the hoses, if applicable; the windshield washer fluid level; the battery connections, fluid level, and tie-downs; the automatic transmission fluid level; and the condition and tightness of the belts. Additionally, check for any leaks in the engine compartment and cracked or worn electrical wiring insulation.

questions.question: When approaching a downgrade, how can you reduce the amount of braking that will be needed?
questions.explanation: Always shift to a lower gear before starting down a hill. Doing this will help your vehicle maintain a safe speed without you needing to use the brakes too much.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pushed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal’s resting position and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop a vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work. On vehicles with hydraulic brakes, the brakes work instantly when the pedal is pressed.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person that motorists should be worried about?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to a passenger in their vehicle
questions.answerB: A child on the side of the road
questions.answerC: A construction worker on the side of the road
questions.answerD: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.explanation: You should be cautious when you are near people who are not paying attention to the road. Be wary of drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers, children near the road, and road workers.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle loses its ABS?
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. If ABS is not working, the basic braking functions on a vehicle will still remain, so the driver can continue to drive and brake normally.

questions.question: If coolant has to be added to a system without a recovery tank, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the vehicle running while adding coolant.
questions.answerC: Not use gloves to touch the radiator cap.
questions.answerD: Wait for the engine to cool before adding coolant.
questions.explanation: Before adding coolant to a system without a recovery or overflow tank, you must turn the engine off and wait until it cools. Use gloves or a thick cloth to protect your hands. To release the pressure seal, turn the radiator cap slowly to the first stop.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time between three-quarters of a second and one second. At 55 mph, this corresponds to a distance of 61 feet traveled.

questions.question: The minimum acceptable tread depth for rear tires is:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch on the other tires. Tires on the same vehicle should all be the same size.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered an encroachment?
questions.answerA: A driver placing the vehicle in neutral and applying the parking brake.
questions.answerB: The vehicle touching an exercise boundary line.
questions.answerC: A driver properly completing an exercise in the skills test.
questions.answerD: An applicant trying to bribe the examiner.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.answerA: It is safe to drive on a tire that is missing one or two lug nuts.
questions.answerB: A cracked lock ring on a rim is safe if you are not driving faster than 55 mph.
questions.answerC: A missing clamp on a rim is dangerous and should be corrected.
questions.explanation: Missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs are dangerous, as are mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings. Be sure your tires and rims are in good condition before operating your commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: Interstate carriers must have what information affixed to the commercial motor vehicles in their fleet?
questions.explanation: Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations (FMCSR) require carriers to affix the legal name or single trade name to each CMV in their fleet.

questions.question: Retreaded tires:
questions.answerA: May be used on any part of a bus.
questions.answerB: May be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: May be used on the rear of a bus.
questions.answerD: May never be used on a bus.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited from use on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: On a slippery surface, stopping distance:
questions.answerA: Is longer than on a regular driving surface.
questions.answerB: Is not as long as on a regular driving surface.
questions.answerC: Is about the same as on a regular driving surface.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's regular stopping distance increases on slippery surfaces because there is less available traction.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person that motorists should be worried about?
questions.answerA: A person talking to another person in their vehicle
questions.answerB: A child on the side of the road
questions.answerC: A construction worker on the side of the road
questions.answerD: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.explanation: You should be cautious when you are near people who are not paying attention to the road. Be wary of drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers, children near the road, and road workers.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle, rough acceleration is:
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: If brakes overheat while going down a downhill grade, they may:
questions.explanation: Overuse of the brakes may cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is known as "fade."

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used if carrying a light load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are never safe to use.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake only needs to be used if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.answerC: The parking brake should not be used, as it can damage the tires.
questions.explanation: In general, you should always use the parking brake when parking your vehicle. However, you should not apply the parking brake if your brakes are very hot or if your brakes are wet and temperatures are below freezing.

questions.question: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by:
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: When driving under wet conditions, what does a lack of spray from other vehicles indicate?
questions.answerA: Ice has formed on the road.
questions.answerC: The spray is caught on the underside of the vehicle.
questions.answerD: The tires have soaked up all the moisture.
questions.explanation: If the road appears to be wet but the wheels of other vehicles are no longer generating spray, ice has formed on the road. Drive with extra caution when operating on wet or icy roads.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started:
questions.answerA: The brakes should be locked up.
questions.answerB: Warning lights should turn on, then quickly turn off.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, you should see the warning lights and buzzers go out right away. If they remain on, there is something wrong with your vehicle.

questions.question: Radial and bias-ply tires:
questions.answerA: Should be used together on all axles.
questions.answerB: Should be used together, but only on the rear axle.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, ensure that radial and bias-ply tires are not being used together.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with power steering, you should inspect:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should look for leaks in the hoses.

questions.question: Overloading a vehicle with cargo can affect all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Overloading can have negative effects on a vehicle's steering, braking and speed control.

questions.question: What must be on an air tank in an air-braked vehicle?
questions.explanation: All air tanks on air-braked vehicles must have one-way check valves located between the air compressor and the first reservoir. This prevents air from flowing out in the event of a leak.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a placarded vehicle, you should always:
questions.answerB: Stop within five feet of the tracks.
questions.answerC: Change gears while on the tracks.
questions.answerD: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a transit bus, school bus, or placarded vehicle, special procedures apply. Before crossing, stop your vehicle within 50 feet of, but not less than 15 feet from, the nearest rail. Activate your four-way flashers while crossing. Do not stop, change gears, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is proceeding across the tracks.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to get out of their way.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, the most important thing to do is try to get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact with the driver and do not let yourself be provoked by gestures. Do not try to challenge aggressive drivers by speeding up.

questions.question: If equipped, a header board should:
questions.answerC: Be strong enough to contain cargo.
questions.answerD: Light up when the engine is started.
questions.explanation: When checking a header board during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that it is secure, free of damage, and strong enough to contain cargo.

questions.question: Who is responsible for cargo that has been loaded onto a truck?
questions.answerA: The person who loaded the truck
questions.explanation: Even if they did not load or secure the cargo themselves, the driver of a vehicle is responsible for inspecting the cargo and ensuring that it is properly secured.

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, the coolant temperature gauge should:
questions.answerA: Not change from its original position.
questions.answerB: Gradually rise to the normal operating range.
questions.answerC: Jump quickly to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: Flash until it reaches the normal operating range.
questions.explanation: Keep an eye on the gauges after starting the engine. The coolant temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, how can you tell if the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working?
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the rear of the trailer will stay on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the trailer will flash three times and then stay on.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights on the trailer will flash and then shut off.
questions.answerD: The blue light near the driver's door will light.
questions.explanation: Trailers equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are equipped on the left rear with a yellow malfunction lamp. If the malfunction lamp stays on after the engine has been started, the ABS is malfunctioning.

questions.question: Areas of the road that are shaded:
questions.answerB: Usually do not contain moisture, so they can’t freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice on other areas of the road has melted.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight, shaded patches of road will stay cooler longer than other areas of the road. Due to the lack of direct sunlight, shady areas can remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to remove the vehicle from the tracks.
questions.answerD: Walk down the tracks to look for an oncoming train.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks for any reason, you should immediately exit the vehicle and walk away from the tracks. Contact the proper emergency authorities.

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: Livestock:
questions.answerA: Should never be transported on a trailer.
questions.answerB: Must be inspected by a law enforcement officer.
questions.answerC: Can cause unsafe handling when being transported on a trailer due to their movement.
questions.answerD: Can only be transported by a person registered as a farmer.
questions.explanation: Livestock being transported as cargo can move around and shift their weight in transit, which can result in unsafe handling.

questions.question: When checking windshield wiper blades, they should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check the wiper blades for damage, stiff rubber, and proper securement. Clean the blades if they are dirty.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: If you’re unfamiliar with the area in which you must back up, you should:
questions.answerA: Get out of your vehicle and walk around the area to become more familiar with it.
questions.answerB: Not use both mirrors, as that can cause too much distraction.
questions.answerC: Wait for someone else to back up in the area so you see how they do it.
questions.answerD: Turn on your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind your vehicle. Especially if you are unfamiliar with the area, you should get out of your vehicle and familiarize yourself with your path of travel before beginning to back up.

questions.question: To make it easier to leave a parked position, you should park:
questions.answerA: In a way that allows you to back up when exiting.
questions.answerB: In a way that allows you to pull forward when exiting.
questions.answerC: Only on the side of roadways, not in parking lots.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible. When parking, look to park in a space that will allow you to pull forward when exiting.

questions.question: Emergency brakes are:
questions.answerD: Only required when transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes.

questions.question: To ensure you do not interfere with traffic while driving a heavy vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to pass other vehicles while driving uphill.
questions.answerD: Ride the brakes while driving downhill.
questions.explanation: If the weight of your vehicle prevents you from matching the speed of surrounding traffic, you should stay in the right lane, if possible.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are on, you should:
questions.answerD: Be especially careful because the brakes may fail.
questions.explanation: You should not apply the brake pedal if the spring brakes are activated. The brakes could be damaged if they are subjected to the force of air pressure and the springs at the same time.

questions.question: After starting a trip while transporting cargo:
questions.answerA: You will not need to inspect the cargo.
questions.answerB: The cargo should only be inspected if it is making noise.
questions.answerC: The cargo should only be inspected if there is an obvious concern.
questions.answerD: The cargo should be inspected after 50 miles on the road to ensure it is still properly secured.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: Trailers should:
questions.answerB: Not be overloaded because it is dangerous.
questions.answerC: Not be overloaded because drivers are only paid to transport certain weights.
questions.answerD: Be loaded with all the weight directly behind the cab.
questions.explanation: Overloading a vehicle is dangerous. It can damage the vehicle and interfere with the driver's ability to control it.

questions.question: The minimum acceptable tread depth for rear tires is:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch on the other tires. Tires on the same vehicle should all be the same size.

questions.question: When driving a truck requiring a CDL:
questions.answerA: You do not need to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You must always wear a seat belt.
questions.explanation: You must be properly restrained by a safety belt at all times when driving a commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.answerD: A minute of hitting the brakes.
questions.explanation: You should always make sure that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: To avoid a crash:
questions.answerA: Braking is always the best option.
questions.answerB: Swerving may be more effective than braking.
questions.answerC: Drivers should leave 100 yards of distance between their vehicle and the next.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the safest response to a hazard on the road. You can almost always turn to avoid an obstacle faster than you can stop.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see other vehicles, such as at dawn or dusk, you should:
questions.explanation: When driving at dawn, at dusk, or in inclement weather, you should use your headlights on their low beam setting to increase your visibility.

questions.question: How many air storage tanks are used in an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air storage tanks are used to hold compressed air. The number and size of air tanks in an air brake system varies among vehicles.

questions.question: Header boards:
questions.answerB: Protect drivers from being hit by cargo.
questions.answerC: Protect drivers' heads when they are entering the cab of a truck.
questions.explanation: A header board protects a driver from moving cargo in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerB: Usually happens when vehicles are traveling at speeds above 65 mph.
questions.answerC: Can occur with a minimal amount of water on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be a large amount of water on the road for this to occur. Hydroplaning can begin at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: When you double your speed from 20 to 40 mph, your vehicle's braking distance will become ____ times longer.
questions.explanation: If you double your speed, your braking distance will become four times longer. Similarly, the impact your vehicle would have in the case of a collision will also multiply by four.

questions.question: How should you check your hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly move toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.answerD: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should be easy to push to the floor.
questions.explanation: To test hydraulic brakes, you should pump the brake pedal three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal and hold for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak.

questions.question: In order to receive a hazardous materials endorsement, a person must complete all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass the HazMat knowledge test; undergo a Federal Security Threat Assessment; provide proof of U.S. citizenship or permanent residency; and undergo an FBI fingerprint check and federal criminal history background check.

questions.question: After a trip:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should be placed out-of-service.
questions.answerB: A vehicle's oil should be changed.
questions.answerC: A vehicle's after-trip inspection should be completed.
questions.answerD: A vehicle's battery should be disconnected.
questions.explanation: After a trip, you may be required to perform an inspection and file a report on each vehicle that you've driven.

questions.question: If driving in a foggy area, you should not:
questions.explanation: It is safest not to drive in foggy areas. However, if you must drive through fog, you should slow down, use your low beam headlights and fog lights, and turn on your four-way flashers.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a possible cause of a fire?
questions.explanation: Possible causes of vehicle fires include spilled fuel or improper use of flares following an crash; under-inflated tires or dual tires that touch; short circuits in the electrical system; smoking around fuel; improper fueling or loose fuel connections; and carrying cargo that is flammable, improperly sealed or loaded, or poorly ventilated.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best advice for driving in fog?
questions.answerA: Try not to drive in fog.
questions.explanation: Driving in fog is always dangerous and should be avoided entirely if at all possible. If you must drive in fog, be sure to turn on your low beam headlights and fog lights, even during the daytime.

questions.question: How much water needs to be on the surface of a road for a vehicle to hydroplane?
questions.answerB: A good amount, such as a large puddle
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be much water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) uses a ____ light to warn that the system is not working properly.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: When operating a vehicle with a dual brake system, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up before driving to ensure that fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Wait to begin driving until the air compressor builds up a minimum pressure of 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the vehicle starts.
questions.answerD: Pump the pedal about 20 times to build pressure, then begin driving.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air system, allow time for the air compressor to build up a minimum pressure of 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: Your CDL will be revoked if:
questions.answerA: You want to add an endorsement.
questions.answerB: Your privilege to operate your personal vehicle is revoked.
questions.answerC: You have not paid a toll.
questions.explanation: If your privilege to operate your personal vehicle is revoked, canceled, or suspended due to moving traffic violations, you will also lose your CDL. This does not apply if your license is revoked due to parking violations.

questions.question: You must put out emergency warning devices within ____ of stopping on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the shoulder of a road, put out your emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping. When pulling off the road to stop, be sure to turn on your four-way emergency flashers.

questions.question: What can happen if one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing when a vehicle is inspected?
questions.answerA: The vehicle’s driver will be allowed to drive, but only at reduced speeds.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be put out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will be fine to drive since most of the spring is in place.
questions.answerD: The driver will be asked to decrease the weight of the load.
questions.explanation: If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: A convex mirror is sometimes called a ____ mirror.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles often have curved, convex mirrors, sometimes referred to as "fisheye," "spot," or "bug-eye" mirrors. These mirrors provide a wider view than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to use your mirrors?
questions.answerC: You are looking at fuel prices.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be part of your normal driving routine, checking your mirrors is especially important when turning, changing lanes, merging, and performing tight maneuvers.

questions.question: Blocking a load:
questions.answerA: Is dangerous and should never be done.
questions.answerC: Is only done with liquid cargo.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks, you should:
questions.explanation: When crossing railroad tracks during the on-road driving skills test, you must not stop, switch gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in the crossing.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Stopping distance is affected by a vehicle's speed. The faster you are driving, the longer your stopping distance will become.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is best to allow more room to open up in front of your vehicle. This will help you avoid the need for sudden stops, which could result in the tailgater rear-ending you, and will make it easier for the tailgater to pass. Speeding up may only make things more dangerous by prompting the other driver to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: If driving a vehicle with a manual transmission, you can prevent your vehicle from rolling backward when starting from a stop by:
questions.answerA: Partly engaging the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Placing the vehicle in reverse before moving forward.
questions.answerC: Fully engaging the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Placing the vehicle in neutral before moving forward.
questions.explanation: To prevent rolling backward when starting from a stop, you should partly engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake. Apply the parking brake whenever necessary to prevent your vehicle from rolling back.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you will need to identify all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must check the power steering belt, water pump belt, alternator belt, and air compressor belt for snugness, cracks, or frays. If any of these components are not belt-driven, you must tell the examiner which one(s), and verify that they are operating properly, mounted securely, and not damaged or leaking.

questions.question: What is another name for front-end header boards?
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: Drivers talking to passengers in their vehicle should be viewed as:
questions.explanation: Drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers may be distracted from the task of driving. Use extra caution when driving near distracted drivers.

questions.question: Livestock:
questions.answerA: Should never be transported on a trailer.
questions.answerB: Must be inspected by a law enforcement officer.
questions.answerC: Can cause unsafe handling when being transported on a trailer due to their movement.
questions.answerD: Can only be transported by a person registered as a farmer.
questions.explanation: Livestock being transported as cargo can move around and shift their weight in transit, which can result in unsafe handling.

questions.question: When taking the driving test and asked to make a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use a turn signal since you were told to make the turn.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only to your right.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and compressor oil from the air tank.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do so can cause damage. Manually operated drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: When parked on the side of the road:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear flashing lights.
questions.answerB: Use only one set of turn signals.
questions.explanation: Always turn on your four-way emergency flashers if you must park on the side of the road. This is especially important when traveling at night.

questions.question: When driving on a wet road, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by about one-third when driving on a wet road.

questions.question: One way to prevent hydroplaning on wet road surfaces is to:
questions.answerA: Ensure that your tires have good tread depth.
questions.explanation: When driving on a wet road surface, the risk of hydroplaning is increased if your tire pressure is too low or your tire tread is too worn. If you begin to hydroplane, release the accelerator and push in the clutch to slow down.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: Eating while driving is:
questions.answerA: A good way to save time.
questions.answerC: Acceptable if you are eating foods that are easy to eat.
questions.explanation: Smoking, eating, or drinking are distracting activities and should be avoided while you are driving. Instead, plan ahead and allow yourself time to stop to eat when making a lengthy trip.

questions.question: When driving, you should stop and take a break ____ to avoid becoming too tired.
questions.explanation: To reduce the chances of becoming fatigued on a long trip, a driver should stop for a break at least once every two hours or 100 miles driven.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is ____ in a minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: Cargo on flatbed trailers should be:
questions.explanation: Cargo on flatbed trailers or trailers without sides must be tied down to prevent it from shifting or falling in transit.

questions.question: During the skills test, if making a turn that requires a stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop after the stop line to get a better view.
questions.answerD: Keep the front wheels aimed straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must come to a stop before making a turn during the driving skills test, you should come to a smooth stop behind any stop line, crosswalk, or stop sign. Keep your front wheels aimed straight ahead and do not let your vehicle roll. If stopping behind another vehicle, stop where you are still able to see the rear tires of the vehicle ahead of you.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of bad brake drums or shoes?
questions.answerD: Shoes that are not covered in brake fluid
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of tie-down equipment?
questions.explanation: You must use the proper number of tie-downs when securing cargo on a flatbed trailer. Examples of tie-down equipment includes ropes, straps, and chains.

questions.question: What can happen if parking brakes are used in very wet weather with temperatures below freezing?
questions.answerB: The brakes may freeze so the vehicle cannot move.
questions.answerC: The brakes may suddenly release by themselves.
questions.answerD: The brakes may become too smooth to be used.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should not be used in very wet weather when temperatures are below freezing. The brakes could become frozen in place, making it impossible to move the vehicle.

questions.question: A commercial motor vehicle driver:
questions.answerA: May use any cell phone while driving.
questions.answerB: May only use a hands-free cell phone while driving, if permitted.
questions.answerC: May only use a cell phone while driving on rural roads.
questions.explanation: If you choose to use a mobile phone while operating a CMV, you may only use a hands-free mobile phone that is located close to you. However, even a hands-free mobile phone can be a dangerous distraction while driving. Make sure you are aware of all cell phone laws in the state in which you are driving.

questions.question: Which of the following vehicles is not exempted in requiring the driver to hold a CDL?
questions.explanation: Subject to certain conditions, a CDL is not required to operate military vehicles, authorized emergency vehicles, farm equipment, or recreational vehicles. It is also not required for operating a straight truck that contains only your personal property that you are not selling.

questions.question: Extremely hot temperatures can cause:
questions.explanation: Because air expands when hot, tire pressure increases as temperatures increase. This can sometimes result in tire failure. Consistently check your tire pressure when making a trip in hot weather.

questions.question: The minimum tread depth of all major grooves on tires that are not on the front of a CMV should be a minimum of:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch on the other tires. Tires on the same vehicle should all be the same size.

questions.question: Which factor does not have an impact on a person’s blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerA: The number of alcoholic drinks consumed
questions.answerB: How quickly the alcoholic drinks were consumed
questions.explanation: The three main factors that determine a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC) are the amount of alcohol consumed, how quickly the alcohol is consumed, and the person's weight.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a driver who might be a hazard?
questions.answerA: A driver operating a vehicle without first scraping ice off the windshield
questions.answerB: The operator of a rental truck
questions.answerC: The driver of a station wagon with items covering the back windows
questions.answerD: A person operating a pick-up truck
questions.explanation: Drivers with blocked vision may pose hazards to others on the road. Examples of such drivers include those who haven't scraped ice off of their windshields; those driving vehicles loaded with large items blocking the windows; and those who are driving rental trucks without being used to the limited rear visibility of a truck.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.explanation: The parking brake in a vehicle with air brakes should be used every time the vehicle is parked.

questions.question: The ____ between an air compressor and reservoir tank prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: If braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add ____ to your vehicle's total stopping distance.
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to a vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: During the basic vehicle control skills test:
questions.answerA: A pull-up always counts against the applicant.
questions.answerB: A pull-up should be completed at least once.
questions.answerC: Stopping without changing direction is not considered a pull-up.
questions.answerD: Excessive pull-ups are acceptable in the opinions of some test administrators.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, a pull-up will be scored any time an applicant stops and pulls forward to gain a better position. Stopping without changing direction will not. An excessive number of pull-ups will count as errors.

questions.question: Which of the following is a time when the vehicle should be downshifted?
questions.explanation: It is particularly important that you downshift before starting down a hill or entering a curve.

questions.question: What color light indicates a vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.explanation: On vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS), yellow malfunction lamps alert the driver to ABS malfunction.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: Radial and bias-ply tires:
questions.answerA: Should be used together on all axles.
questions.answerB: Should be used together, but only on the rear axle.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, ensure that radial and bias-ply tires are not being used together.

questions.question: If planning to stop on the road to unload cargo, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop suddenly, since you are already on the road.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers by tapping your brakes.
questions.answerC: Wave your arm out the window to get the attention of other drivers.
questions.explanation: You should tap your brakes and flash your brake lights to warn other drivers any time you plan to slow or stop where other drivers may not expect you to do so. Use this technique when stopping on the road to unload cargo or passengers.

questions.question: On low bridges:
questions.answerA: Height warnings must always be posted.
questions.answerB: Height warnings must be posted at least twice.
questions.answerC: Height warnings may be posted, but do not have to be.
questions.explanation: Height warnings are often, but not always, posted on low bridges. If you are unsure if you will be able to clear an overhead object, go slowly.

questions.question: When checking your tires as part of the pre-trip inspection, you should look at the:
questions.explanation: When checking your tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, it is important to verify that the tire pressure is neither too low nor too high.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn the steering wheel as hard as possible.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch. This will help you to regain traction.

questions.question: When inspecting your vehicle, which of the following should not cause concern?
questions.answerA: Exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts
questions.answerB: Exhaust system parts that are leaking
questions.answerD: Exhaust system parts made of aluminum
questions.explanation: Problems to check for when inspecting a vehicle's exhaust system include loose, broken, or missing exhaust pipes, mufflers, tailpipes, or vertical stacks; loose, broken, or missing mounting brackets, clamps, bolts, or nuts; exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts, tires, or other moving parts of the vehicle; and exhaust system parts that are leaking.

questions.question: How could you reduce your stress while driving?
questions.explanation: Being under stress can lead to aggressive driving, which is dangerous. Playing calming music can help you become more relaxed if you are feeling stressed while driving.

questions.question: In low temperatures, bridges usually freeze:
questions.answerA: After other parts of the roadway.
questions.answerB: Before other parts of the roadway.
questions.answerC: At the same time as other parts of the roadway.
questions.explanation: In low temperatures, bridges usually freeze before other road surfaces. When driving in cold weather, especially when weather conditions have been wet, use special caution on bridges and overpasses.

questions.question: Which of the following could reduce the amount of space between the road surface and an overhead object, such as a bridge?
questions.explanation: You should not assume that signs marking the height of a bridge or overpass are exactly correct. If the road was repaved after the sign went up, or if snow is on the ground, the clearance may be different than what the sign indicates.

questions.question: Mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.answerC: When you are standing next to the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Mirrors should be checked prior to the beginning of a trip. On a vehicle with a trailer, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the connected trailer is straight.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tank drains are used to remove water and compressor oil from the air tanks. When operating a drain, be sure to drain the tank completely.

questions.question: If equipped, a header board should:
questions.answerC: Be strong enough to contain cargo.
questions.answerD: Light up when the engine is started.
questions.explanation: When checking a header board during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that it is secure, free of damage, and strong enough to contain cargo.

questions.question: What must be done if a load is over-length?
questions.answerA: A warning flag must be placed on the end of the load.
questions.answerB: The load may only be transported between 6 p.m. and 3 a.m.
questions.answerD: The emergency flashers must be activated.
questions.explanation: Special equipment, such as warning flags or flashing lights, may be required if you are transporting an over-length load. When transporting such a a load, you will need to acquire the necessary permits. Driving is often limited to certain times.

questions.question: During an inspection, slack adjusters on S-cam brakes should not move more than:
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after parking on level ground, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Prepare to proceed as soon as a train passes.
questions.answerC: Open the door to listen for approaching trains.
questions.explanation: When stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, do not rely only on signals to tell you if a train is approaching. You should silence all passengers, open the front door, and look and listen for trains. After a train has passed, you should check for another train approaching from either direction before you proceed across the tracks.

questions.question: What should be used to check for proper tire inflation?
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must use a tire gauge to check for proper tire inflation. You will not receive passing credit if you simply kick the tires.

questions.question: While students load and unload a bus, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Watch the process and keep an eye on the students.
