questions.explanation: The driver of a school bus should observe students as they enter or exit the bus to ensure that they are not caught in the door or handrails. It is also important to make sure the students have moved a safe distance away from the unloading area after they have exited the bus.

questions.question: How far in advance of a school bus stop should a bus's lights be activated?
questions.explanation: If a school bus is equipped with alternating flashing amber warning lights, they should be activated at least 200 feet (approximately 5 to 10 seconds) before a stop, unless state law requires otherwise.

questions.question: In the event of a bus evacuation, students should be led at least ____ away from the road.
questions.explanation: If it is necessary to evacuate a school bus, students should be led by the driver in the direction of oncoming traffic to a safe location that is at least 100 feet off the road. This will help to ensure that they are not hit by flying debris if another vehicle hits the bus.

questions.question: If a driver needs to exit a school bus to ensure all waiting students have boarded, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Turn the bus off and take the key.
questions.answerC: Ask a student to keep an eye on the steering wheel.
questions.explanation: While students are boarding a school bus, if the driver cannot account for a student outside, they should secure the bus, take the key with them, and check around and underneath the bus for the missing student.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stop, the bus driver should:
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should always approach bus stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: When exiting your vehicle, you must maintain ____ with the vehicle at all times.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If your vehicle's ABS is malfunctioning:
questions.answerA: You will not have any working brakes.
questions.answerC: You should only use the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Anti-lock brakes are meant to keep a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard applications. If your vehicle's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunctions, its standard braking functions should still be in place. You should continue to drive and brake in a normal manner.

questions.question: When encountering a railroad crossing during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is moving too slowly.
questions.answerB: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: The drive shaft should:
questions.answerA: Be bent toward the passenger side.
questions.answerB: Be bent toward the driver’s side.
questions.answerC: Be bent to one side or the other.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you should check that the drive shaft is not bent or cracked.

questions.question: After students unload at the school, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Not be concerned with the students' whereabouts.
questions.answerB: Leave after the students have entered the school building.
questions.answerC: Walk through the bus to check for any sleeping students.
questions.explanation: After students unload at school, a school bus driver should walk through the bus to check for sleeping students, hiding students, and items that students may have left behind. Students should exit the bus in an orderly fashion with the driver supervising.

questions.question: When alley docking, your vehicle should be parked:
questions.answerA: With the front bumper on top of the front boundary line.
questions.answerB: With the rear wheels over the rear boundary line.
questions.answerC: Straight within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.answerD: At an angle within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: The loading of a school bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading.

questions.question: During the pre-trip inspection test, you will be:
questions.answerA: Expected to explain your knowledge of the pre-trip process.
questions.answerB: Watching someone else check your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Watching a film on how to inspect a vehicle.
questions.answerD: Changing all the tires on your vehicle.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: When operating a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.explanation: It is critical to the safe operation of a school bus that mirrors be properly adjusted. Always check each mirror before operating the bus.

questions.question: When students are boarding a school bus, the driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Let students know when it is safe to board.
questions.answerB: Count the number of students at the bus stop and ensure that all have boarded.
questions.answerC: Allow student to board in pairs.
questions.answerD: Check all mirrors for students rushing toward the bus.
questions.explanation: Students should always board a school bus in a single-file line.

questions.question: To safely unload a bus, students should:
questions.answerA: Remain seated until they are told to exit.
questions.answerB: Stand up and head toward the door while the bus is slowing down.
questions.answerC: Exit the bus and stand directly next to the bus while it is being driven away from the stop.
questions.explanation: Students who are about to unload a school bus should remain seated until the driver tells them that it is safe to exit. After exiting the bus, they should walk to a position that is at least 10 feet away from the bus so the driver can clearly see them.

questions.question: Active railroad crossings:
questions.answerB: Do not have any traffic control devices installed.
questions.answerC: Are crossed by at least 10 vehicles every hour.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings with control devices to regulate traffic are known as active crossings. Control devices may include regulators such as flashing red lights, warning bells, and gates. Drivers are required by law to follow instructions given by control devices.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: If a driver cannot account for a student after the student has exited the bus, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure and leave the bus to look for the student.
questions.answerB: Assume the student has safely exited the bus.
questions.answerC: Walk to the back of the bus to see if the student got back on.
questions.answerD: Ask another student if they've seen the student.
questions.explanation: During unloading, if a school bus driver cannot account for a student outside of the bus, they should secure the bus and check for the missing student around and underneath the bus.

questions.question: When taking the driving test and asked to make a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use a turn signal since you were told to make the turn.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only to your right.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: A school bus's danger zones are located:
questions.answerA: Only to the front of the bus.
questions.answerB: Only to the rear and left side of the bus.
questions.answerC: To the front, sides, and rear of the bus.
questions.explanation: The danger zones of a school bus are areas in which children are most likely to be hit, either by another vehicle or by the bus itself. Such areas are located to the front, sides, and rear of a bus. Danger zones can extend 10 feet from every side of a bus.

questions.question: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Prepare to proceed as soon as a train passes.
questions.answerC: Open the door to listen for approaching trains.
questions.explanation: When stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, do not rely only on signals to tell you if a train is approaching. You should silence all passengers, open the front door, and look and listen for trains. After a train has passed, you should check for another train approaching from either direction before you proceed across the tracks.

questions.question: ABS allows you to:
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) help prevent brake lockup when driving on slippery surfaces. If a driver brakes too hard on a slippery surface, ABS makes it easier for the driver to maintain control of their vehicle. A vehicle equipped with ABS should be driven and braked in the same way as a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: If exiting a bus, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Never make contact with the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: A bus driver approaching a bus stop should stop at least 10 feet away from waiting students because:
questions.answerA: The students will have to walk to the bus, making it easier to see their movements.
questions.answerC: The students may get scared of the bus coming toward them.
questions.explanation: At a stop, a school bus should be stopped with the front bumper at least 10 feet away from the students. This forces the students to walk toward the bus, allowing the driver to keep an eye on their movements.

questions.question: When stopping to pick up students, a bus driver should:
questions.answerB: Place the vehicle in first gear.
questions.answerD: Place the vehicle in third gear.
questions.explanation: When stopping to pick up students, a school bus should be put in park. If the transmission does not have a park shift point, the vehicle should instead be placed in neutral.

questions.question: If a bus stalls on a railroad track, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Evacuate the bus and get everyone far away from the tracks.
questions.answerB: Keep everyone inside the bus and try to wave the train down to make it stop.
questions.answerC: Keep everyone inside the bus and wait for help.
questions.answerD: Keep everyone inside the bus and call a tow truck.
questions.explanation: If a school bus becomes stalled or trapped on railroad tracks, the driver should immediately evacuate everyone from the bus. To best avoid flying debris from the bus being struck by a train, the students should be led far away from the bus at an angle that is in the direction of any oncoming train.

questions.question: Once stopped as a part of the stop/start maneuver, you should:
questions.answerB: Not use the four-way flashers because it is just a test, not an emergency.
questions.answerC: Leave the vehicle in first gear.
questions.answerD: Park in front of a fire hydrant.
questions.explanation: Once you have stopped as a part of the stop/start maneuver during the on-road driving skills test, you must activate your four-way flashers and shift into neutral or park. You must not block any driveways, intersections, fire hydrants, or signs.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that lug nuts are all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: During a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that all lug nuts are present, free of cracks and distortions, and showing no signs of looseness, such as rust trails or shiny threads. Verify that all bolt holes are free of cracks and distortions.

questions.question: When checking tire condition during the vehicle inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the insides of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the outsides of the tires are more worn than the insides of the tires.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the middles of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the tires have even wear.
questions.explanation: When examining your tires during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that treads are evenly worn.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test, failing to exit your vehicle properly during any exercise will result in:
questions.answerB: An extra point against your final score.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: When students are being picked up by a school bus:
questions.answerA: The students should wait at a designated bus stop.
questions.answerB: The driver should pick up students whether or not they are at the designated bus stop.
questions.answerC: The parents should choose where the bus stop will be located.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should load and unload students only at designated stops that have been approved by appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle controls skills test exercise, your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: In the general area that was described by the examiner.
questions.answerB: In the exact final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerC: Within three feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: When loading or unloading passengers, a school bus should be placed in ____ if there is no park shift point available.
questions.explanation: When stopping to load or unload students, a school bus should ideally be placed in park. If there is no park shift point, the bus should be placed in neutral and the parking brake should be set.

questions.question: As a general rule, where should students be kept during an emergency?
questions.answerB: On the side of the road near the bus
questions.answerC: In a field away from the bus
questions.explanation: In most emergency or crisis situations, students on a school bus will be safer and more easily controlled if they are kept on the bus than if they are evacuated. However, if staying on a bus will expose the students to risk or injury, the bus driver should escort them to a safe location.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerD: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: If a tornado is approaching and the bus is evacuated, where should students go?
questions.explanation: If students are evacuated due to a school bus being in the direct path of a sighted tornado, the driver should lead them to shelter in a nearby building. If no such shelter is available, the driver should escort them to a nearby ditch or culvert. They should avoid areas that may be subject to flash flooding and should be far enough from the bus that it would not fall on them if it tipped over.

questions.question: School bus stops may be changed by:
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should not change the location of a stop without written approval from appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: May only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerC: May be driven if the cargo is not radioactive.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that lacks the proper placards for any hazardous materials on board may not be driven, except as necessary to protect life and property in an emergency.

questions.question: If a shipping paper has both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials should be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.answerC: Written the same way as the non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: When a shipping paper includes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, one acceptable method of identifying the hazardous items is to highlight them in a contrasting color.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerA: Does not have to be able to move the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Does not need to know about the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must stay within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading and unloading of a tank must be watched by a qualified person. They must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the materials involved; know the procedures to follow in an emergency; and be authorized and able to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: The amount of packaging required to make the shipment.
questions.answerC: The location on the trailer where items may be placed.
questions.answerD: How the material should be loaded and unloaded.
questions.explanation: There are nine different hazard classes. A material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers must include:
questions.answerC: The intended use of the materials.
questions.answerD: The country of origin of the materials.
questions.explanation: Drivers must be aware of the risks associated with materials they are transporting. Hazardous materials shipping papers must include an emergency response telephone number.

questions.question: If a package of explosives has an oily stain or shows dampness, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Use towels to absorb the liquid.
questions.explanation: You should never transport damaged packages of explosives. Do not accept a package that seems damp or has an oily stain.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in a trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.answerC: Left to air dry without washing.
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to corrosive liquids must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: Shippers must keep a copy of shipping papers for:
questions.explanation: Shippers must retain a physical copy or an electronic image of hazardous materials shipping papers for a minimum of two years after the materials are accepted by the initial carrier. For hazardous waste, this increases to three years.

questions.question: A Class 7 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: Radioactive materials are categorized as Class 7 hazardous materials.

questions.question: On packages that are not large enough to hold a HazMat label, materials should be labeled:
questions.answerC: With a piece of orange tape.
questions.explanation: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to display the proper label, the label may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually shaped like what?
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are diamond-shaped.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle may be:
questions.answerB: Either awake or asleep inside the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A person attending a parked placarded vehicle must be either awake inside the vehicle or they must be within 100 feet of it. If not inside the vehicle itself, the person must have a clear view of the vehicle. The person attending may not be inside the sleeper berth.

questions.question: If you notice a cargo leak, you should identify the leaking hazardous materials by:
questions.explanation: If you discover a cargo leak while transporting hazardous materials, use the shipping papers, label, or package location to identify which materials are involved. Do not try to touch or smell the leaking materials to determine what they are because doing so could result in injury or death.

questions.question: If your engine runs a pump used during delivery of compressed gas, you should turn off the engine:
questions.explanation: Unless your engine runs a pump for product transfer, turn it off when loading or unloading a compressed gas tank. If you do use your engine to run a pump, you should turn the engine off after the product transfer but before unhooking the hoses.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a shipping paper?
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: In the event of a fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerC: Find someone else to open the doors.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. In this case, leave the doors closed because opening the doors could worsen the fire by supplying it with more oxygen.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on a package, a ____ placard must be used.
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on a package or its shipping paper, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate, must be displayed.

questions.question: The person loading a tank with hazardous materials must be all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Aware of the hazards associated with the materials.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the package must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages containing liquid containers should display arrows pointing in the correct upright direction. These packages should be placed facing the correct direction.

questions.question: How often do hazardous materials employees need to be trained?
questions.answerB: At least once every three years
questions.explanation: Employees who work with hazardous materials must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed, except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, your vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of the road.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerC: Does not need to know the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must be within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading of a tank with hazardous materials must always be watched by a qualified person. This person must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 items should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) materials, heaters are generally prohibited.

questions.question: You may leave a vehicle that is carrying explosives unattended:
questions.answerC: On the shoulder of a highway.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: Regulations relating to hazardous materials are intended to protect:
questions.explanation: Transporting hazardous materials can be risky. The regulations are intended to protect you, those around you, and the environment.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be in the vehicle?
questions.explanation: If transporting chlorine in cargo tanks, a driver must have an approved gas mask in their vehicle.

questions.question: Which type of material may be required to have a transport index?
questions.explanation: Some radioactive materials are required to be accompanied by a transport index. A transport index is a number that indicates how much control the material will require during transport. The total transport index of all cargo in a single vehicle may not exceed 50.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may be:
questions.answerA: Kept in a pouch attached to the driver's side door.
questions.answerB: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: A person who is watching the loading or unloading of a tank must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Remain within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.answerD: Know the hazards of the materials involved.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: What does a hazardous materials shipping paper describe?
questions.answerB: How the materials will be transported
questions.answerC: Who should accept the materials being transported
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes the hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: If transporting mass explosives:
questions.answerA: The vehicle must always be placarded.
questions.answerB: The vehicle only needs to be placarded if carrying more than 200 pounds.
questions.answerC: The vehicle does not need to be placarded.
questions.answerD: Only rural roads should be used.
questions.explanation: For some hazardous materials, placards are only required to be used if 1,001 pounds or more are being carried by a vehicle. For others, including mass explosives, placards are required to be used when carrying any amount of the material.

questions.question: How must a shipper notify a driver of the risks associated with their cargo?
questions.answerB: By writing a note on a blank piece of paper
questions.answerC: By putting hazard warning labels on packages
questions.answerD: By placing orange dots on packages
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous cargo must alert drivers and others to relevant hazards through proper shipping papers, hazard warning labels on packages, emergency response information, and placards.

questions.question: How long do shippers need to keep a copy of shipping papers for hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials must retain a copy or electronic image of the associated shipping papers for at least two years from the date that the material is accepted by the initial carrier. For hazardous waste, this increases to three years.

questions.question: If you apply for an original or renewal HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a background check conducted by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: If a driver is given a leaking package or shipment, they should:
questions.answerC: Leave it on the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Get someone else to drive it.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to refuse packages or shipments of hazardous materials if they contain leaks.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you must park at least ____ from any building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, do not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building; a place where people gather; or an open fire.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually which shape?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: To know which placard to use, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard class of the materials.
questions.answerB: The type of container that is holding the materials.
questions.explanation: To determine which placards need to be used, you must know the hazard class of the materials being shipped, the amount of hazardous materials being shipped, and the total weight of all hazardous materials in your vehicle.

questions.question: If a product requires a "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard, the placard must be used when transporting:
questions.answerA: More than 50 pounds of the product.
questions.answerB: More than 10 pounds of the product.
questions.answerD: The product in a non-sealed container.
questions.explanation: For applicable materials, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard and the appropriate hazard class placard must always be displayed, even for small amounts of the materials.

questions.question: How do you label a package if the hazardous materials label will not fit onto the package?
questions.answerA: Place the label on a tag securely attached to the item.
questions.answerB: Attach a QR Code to be scanned.
questions.answerC: Reduce the size of the HazMat label to fit it completely on the item.
questions.explanation: Shippers should place applicable diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on hazardous materials packages. If a label will not fit entirely onto a package, shippers may instead place the label on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerC: Does not need to know the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must be within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading of a tank with hazardous materials must always be watched by a qualified person. This person must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials must be listed first.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials must be written larger.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials must be listed in red ink.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper lists both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be entered first.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package:
questions.answerB: Has been prepared in compliance with the rules.
questions.answerC: Was packed at a specific location.
questions.answerD: Will be placed on the trailer first.
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they are certifying that the package has been prepared in accordance with its applicable rules.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Drive to find a phone to alert emergency personnel
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean up facility
questions.answerC: Park the vehicle and contact emergency personnel
questions.explanation: In the event of a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, do not continue to drive any longer than is necessary for safety. Continuing to drive would result in a larger area becoming contaminated. Instead, park the vehicle, secure the area, stay with the vehicle, and send someone to get help.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on a package, a ____ placard must be used.
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on a package or its shipping paper, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate, must be displayed.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: If a driver is given a leaking package or shipment, they should:
questions.answerC: Leave it on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to refuse packages or shipments of hazardous materials if they contain leaks.

questions.question: What is used to warn people about hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped warning signs, called "placards," are placed on the outside of a vehicle carrying hazardous materials to serve as a warning.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in a trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.answerC: Left to air dry without washing.
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to corrosive liquids must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle may be:
questions.answerB: Either awake or asleep inside the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A person attending a parked placarded vehicle must be either awake inside the vehicle or they must be within 100 feet of it. If not inside the vehicle itself, the person must have a clear view of the vehicle. The person attending may not be inside the sleeper berth.

questions.question: In the Hazardous Materials Table, Column 2 lists:
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must carry a fire extinguisher with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: If transporting explosives, you may leave your vehicle unattended:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is shaped like a:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are diamond-shaped.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials, a driver:
questions.answerA: Should not cross a railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching a railroad crossing, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, you must stop before crossing railroad tracks. This is true whether the tanks are full or empty.

questions.question: Placarded vehicles must carry fire extinguishers with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: Brake fading is caused when:
questions.answerA: Brakes are not used often enough.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes excessively will cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is referred to as "fading."

questions.question: During an inspection, slack adjusters on S-cam brakes should not move more than:
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after parking on level ground, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of retarder?
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow the vehicle and reduce the need for braking. The four basic types of retarders are exhaust, engine, hydraulic, and electric.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Should not be used in cold weather.
questions.answerB: Are helpful to remove water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerC: Are used to move air to the brakes.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually has a certain amount of water and oil in it. This can harm the system if allowed to accumulate. Air tanks have drain valves to aid in removing water and oil from the compressed air.

questions.question: When backing, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Rely only on the passenger’s side mirror.
questions.answerC: Turn toward the passenger’s side whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should back up slowly and use the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle. Use a helper to monitor your blind spots whenever possible. You and the helper should agree on a signal for "stop."

questions.question: The steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held by one hand to allow for other tasks, such as eating and drinking.
questions.answerC: Held by one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: Cracked to allow for an improved grip.
questions.explanation: To maintain proper control of your vehicle, the steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands. Your hands should be positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Make sure your glasses are clean.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you can see as well as possible, don't wear sunglasses when driving at night. If you wear eyeglasses, make sure they are clean and unscratched. Make sure you are rested and alert before driving at night.

questions.question: While uncoupling, the landing gear should be:
questions.explanation: Landing gear, or trailer supports, should always be completely raised before a vehicle is driven. When uncoupling, landing gear should be lowered to make firm contact with the ground. If a trailer is loaded when it is being uncoupled, you should lower the landing gear and turn the crank a few additional times to remove some weight from the trailer.

questions.question: When approaching a vehicle for a pre-trip inspection, a driver should look under the vehicle:
questions.answerA: To see if the vehicle is on an incline.
questions.answerB: To see if there are any fresh fluids on the ground.
questions.answerC: To see if the vehicle is in a parking spot.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle before an inspection, make note of its general condition and ensure that it is not damaged or leaning. Look under the vehicle for fresh leaks of oil, grease, or fuel. Check around the vehicle for hazards to movement, such as people, other vehicles, or low-hanging wires or tree limbs.

questions.question: Which of the following could reduce the amount of space between the road surface and an overhead object, such as a bridge?
questions.explanation: You should not assume that signs marking the height of a bridge or overpass are exactly correct. If the road was repaved after the sign went up, or if snow is on the ground, the clearance may be different than what the sign indicates.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerB: Still allows you additional control when braking.
questions.answerC: Slows the vehicle, but cannot stop it.
questions.explanation: If you have an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) equipped on only the tractor, only the trailer, or only one axle, you will still have more control over the vehicle when braking than you would without ABS. You should brake normally.

questions.question: Which of the following is not part of a vehicle’s air brake system?
questions.explanation: Components of an air brake system include an air compressor, an air compressor governor, air storage tanks, air tank drains, an alcohol evaporator, a safety valve, a brake pedal, foundation brakes, supply pressure gauges, an application pressure gauge, a low air pressure warning signal, a stop light switch, a front brake limiting valve (on some older vehicles), spring brakes, and parking brake controls.

questions.question: Antifreeze helps to keep an engine functioning properly:
questions.answerD: While minimizing the vehicle's fuel use.
questions.explanation: It is always important to have enough water and antifreeze in a vehicle's cooling system. Despite the name, antifreeze is beneficial to an engine even in hot weather.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerC: Between three-quarters of a second and one second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time of between three-quarters of a second and one second.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downhill.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used when transporting cargo.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should not be used for parking. This could cause all of the air to leak out of the braking system, resulting in the brakes releasing. Instead, use the parking brake.

questions.question: When coupling a trailer:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple the proper glad hands.
questions.answerB: Glad hands can be connected to any other glad hands.
questions.answerC: Only one set of glad hands should be connected.
questions.explanation: When coupling, make sure you couple matching glad hands. They are often color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: Which of the following types of vehicles is most prone to the “crack-the-whip" effect?
questions.explanation: Double and triple combinations are the most vulnerable to turning over as a result of the "crack-the-whip" effect.

questions.question: When driving a double or triple, it is important to remember that:
questions.answerA: The vehicle requires more space than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Other drivers will likely get out of your way when necessary.
questions.answerC: The vehicle likely weighs the same as other vehicles.
questions.answerD: The vehicle can easily fit into small spaces.
questions.explanation: Doubles and triples need more space than other vehicles, both because they are longer than other vehicles and because their size and weight prevent them from turning or stopping suddenly. When driving a double or triple, always make sure you have enough space before entering traffic, crossing traffic, or changing lanes.

questions.question: If a speed limit is posted, the posted speed:
questions.answerB: May be exceeded if passing another vehicle.
questions.answerC: May be exceeded if driving in a rural area.
questions.explanation: A maximum posted speed limit is the fastest a vehicle may travel under ideal circumstances. A driver should decrease their driving speed as conditions require. A driver should never exceed the legal speed limit.

questions.question: Which of the following surfaces provides the least amount of traction?
questions.explanation: Be especially cautious when driving on ice that has begun to melt. Ice that is wet is much more slippery than ice that is dry.

questions.question: Radial and bias-ply tires:
questions.answerB: Should be used together on the front of a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Radial and bias-ply tires should not be used together. All wheels on a vehicle should be the same style and equally-sized.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, you must first turn the steering wheel:
questions.answerA: In the direction you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerB: In the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to go.
questions.explanation: When backing a vehicle without a trailer, a driver must turn the vehicle in the direction that they want to go. However, when backing with a trailer, the driver must begin by turning in the opposite direction. Once the trailer starts to turn, they should turn the wheel in the other direction to follow the trailer.

questions.question: When a construction worker is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerD: Wait to proceed until the construction is complete.
questions.explanation: In construction zones, do not exceed the posted safe sped limit. Slow down even more when workers are near the roadway.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is best to allow more room to open up in front of your vehicle. This will help you avoid the need for sudden stops, which could result in the tailgater rear-ending you, and will make it easier for the tailgater to pass. Speeding up may only make things more dangerous by prompting the other driver to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern since it is stopped.
questions.answerB: Is only a concern if passengers are exiting the bus.
questions.answerC: Is a concern whether or not passengers are visible.
questions.explanation: You should always exercise caution when driving near a stopped bus. There could be passengers in the vicinity and the bus may either prevent them from seeing you or you from seeing them.

questions.question: Rearward amplification refers to:
questions.answerA: The amount of noise projected to the rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: The number of trailers that can be pulled by a tractor.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with trailers are vulnerable to rollover due to the "crack-the-whip" effect, which is caused by rearward amplification.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash on the road ahead of you, you should:
questions.answerA: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop after the crash scene and report the driver’s aggressive behavior to the police.
questions.answerC: Continue driving and mind your own business.
questions.answerD: Pull over and yell at the driver.
questions.explanation: If you observe a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: If the brakes “pull” to one side or the other when you use them, it's a sign that:
questions.answerB: The brakes need to be checked.
questions.answerD: The brakes have too much stopping power.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle "pulls" to one side when braking, you may have brake trouble. If there is an issue with your brakes, you should fix the issue before driving. Operating an unsafe vehicle is against federal and state laws.

questions.question: To use the controlled braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half-force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes until the wheels lock.
questions.explanation: The method of controlled braking involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. If you need to make large steering adjustments while using controlled braking, you should remove your foot from the brake pedal, steer, then reapply the brakes.

questions.question: Vehicles with low underneath clearance may be difficult to drive:
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: On low bridges:
questions.answerA: Height warnings must always be posted.
questions.answerB: Height warnings must be posted at least twice.
questions.answerC: Height warnings may be posted, but do not have to be.
questions.explanation: Height warnings are often, but not always, posted on low bridges. If you are unsure if you will be able to clear an overhead object, go slowly.

questions.question: The minimum size of placards identifying hazardous materials is:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be at least 10 and three-quarter inches square.

questions.question: Brake fading is caused when:
questions.answerA: Brakes are not used often enough.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes excessively will cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is referred to as "fading."

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely pass under an upcoming bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you are not confident that your vehicle will have enough room to safely pass under an overhead object, you should slow down and seek another route, if possible.

questions.question: On any upgrade, gravity will:
questions.answerC: Not impact the speed of your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Cause your vehicle to swerve to the left.
questions.explanation: When driving uphill, you are fighting the force of gravity, which will slow down your vehicle.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerB: Only happens when drivers are physically doing something, like using a cell phone.
questions.answerC: Can occur due to mental activities, such as daydreaming.
questions.explanation: Mental distractions can be just as dangerous as physical ones. It is possible for a person to look right at a hazard on the road but fail to notice it because their thoughts are occupied by something else.

questions.question: When are people usually the least alert?
questions.explanation: Most drivers are the least alert at night, especially after midnight. Therefore, crashes due to fatigued driving are more likely at night than any other time of day.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: Dollies equipped with ABS are required to have malfunction lamps located where?
questions.explanation: A dolly equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is required to have a yellow malfunction lamp located on its left side.

questions.question: What does the trailer air supply control look like?
questions.answerA: It is a square blue knob.
questions.answerB: It is a triangular yellow knob.
questions.answerC: It is an eight-sided red knob.
questions.answerD: It is a circular orange knob.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles, the trailer air supply control is an eight-sided red knob. It's used to control the tractor protection valve.

questions.question: Why should the steps of a pre-trip inspection be done in the same order each time?
questions.answerA: You will be less likely to forget a step.
questions.answerD: The form must be followed in order.
questions.explanation: Doing an inspection the same way every time will help you learn the necessary steps. You will be less likely to forget a step if you get into a routine.

questions.question: The easiest way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.answerC: Release the brake pedal and then push it down again.
questions.answerD: Watch the jackknife warning light on the control panel.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to spot a trailer skid is to use your mirrors. Any time you brake hard, check your mirrors to ensure that your trailer is still in its proper position.

questions.question: If feeling tired while driving, it is best to:
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the only safe action to take is to stop and get some sleep. Trying to fight the fatigue and press on is very dangerous and can result in a fatal crash. You should not rely on artificial stimulants; these may help keep you awake a while longer, but they won't make you more alert.

questions.question: Having anti-lock brakes on only one axle:
questions.answerA: Will not make a difference in braking.
questions.answerB: Will provide increased control in braking.
questions.answerC: Will likely cause the air brakes to malfunction.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle has anti-lock brakes on just one axle, the driver will still have more control during braking than they would without any anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: Looking far ahead of your vehicle while driving is:
questions.answerA: Discouraged, as there is little you can do about something far up the road.
questions.answerB: Encouraged to help you identify hazards as early as possible.
questions.answerD: Only encouraged if you are transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Good drivers look down the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. This makes it possible to identify hazards early, when drivers are more likely to have time to respond appropriately.

questions.question: A manifest for transporting hazardous waste:
questions.answerC: Must be attached to the outside of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting hazardous waste, you must carry with you a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. The manifest must be signed by hand.

questions.question: As part of a pre-trip inspection, you should look for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Tires with too much air pressure.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch in grooves on the other tires. Be sure that your tires are not too worn, are not cracked, have proper air pressure, and are all equally sized.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch. This will help you to regain traction.

questions.question: An open automobile window in cold weather may indicate that the driver is:
questions.answerC: Using the heat inside their vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' behaviors and identify clues that indicate when person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. A person driving with their window open in cold weather may be impaired.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: You should always make sure that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern since it is stopped.
questions.answerB: Is only a concern if passengers are exiting the bus.
questions.answerC: Is a concern whether or not passengers are visible.
questions.explanation: You should always exercise caution when driving near a stopped bus. There could be passengers in the vicinity and the bus may either prevent them from seeing you or you from seeing them.

questions.question: In an empty combination vehicle, the stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have:
questions.explanation: An empty combination vehicle will come to a complete stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle. With less weight in a trailer, the stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have lower traction than they would if the vehicle carried more weight.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerC: There is a lot of traffic.
questions.answerD: Vehicles are too close to one another.
questions.explanation: A rollover happens as a result of a driver changing lanes or turning too quickly.

questions.question: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should not:
questions.answerB: Check the coolant level in the radiator.
questions.answerD: Check the windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should check the oil level, coolant level, and windshield washer fluid level, among other things.

questions.question: What is reaction distance?
questions.answerA: The distance you will travel between realizing you must brake and when you physically hit the brakes
questions.answerB: The distance you will travel between a hazard becoming visible and you seeing the hazard
questions.answerC: The distance you will travel between seeing a hazard and realizing you must brake
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's stopping distance can be calculated by adding together your perception distance, your reaction distance, and your vehicle's braking distance. Reaction distance is the distance traveled between the moment you mentally perceive a hazard and the moment you physically hit the brakes.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely travel under a bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you aren't sure that you have space for your vehicle to safely fit underneath an overhead object, slow down and seek an alternate route if possible.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good rule to follow when using turn signals?
questions.answerC: Do not use your turn signal if you think others know what you plan to do.
questions.answerD: Cancel your signal after the turn is completed.
questions.explanation: To be certain that others are aware of your intentions, always signal whenever you plan to turn or change lanes. You should signal well in advance of a turn; signal continuously throughout the turn; and make sure to cancel the signal when you are finished turning.

questions.question: One way to prevent drowsiness while driving is to:
questions.answerC: Get adequate sleep the night before the trip.
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness. Exercising regularly can increase your energy levels and make you less likely to become tired while driving.

questions.question: A driver should stop after a short distance after changing a tire to:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the wheel nuts are tight on the newly-changed tire.
questions.answerB: Ensure that there is still enough air pressure in the tire.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the correct tire was changed.
questions.answerD: Ensure that changing one tire did not damage another tire.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop after a short distance to re-check the tightness of the wheel nuts.

questions.question: In the event of a fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerC: Find someone else to open the doors.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. In this case, leave the doors closed because opening the doors could worsen the fire by supplying it with more oxygen.

questions.question: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is equipped on a trailer but not on a tractor:
questions.answerA: The truck should not be driven because ABS needs to be on both the tractor and trailer.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven more slowly than usual.
questions.answerC: The tractor should not be used and a new tractor with ABS should be located.
questions.answerD: The tractor and trailer can still be used together.
questions.explanation: A vehicle being equipped with anti-lock brakes on only the tractor or only the trailer provides additional control during braking.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method while transporting liquid cargo, you should apply the brakes:
questions.answerA: With about half of your usual force.
questions.answerB: As hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerC: Completely until the wheels lock up. Release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, and then the process is repeated.

questions.question: Which of the following is not required emergency equipment?
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher. Optional equipment includes tire chains, tire changing equipment, a list of emergency phone numbers, and an accident reporting kit/packet.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when air pressure drops to a level between:
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: If the emergency air line loses pressure:
questions.answerA: The Anti-Lock Braking System will activate.
questions.answerB: The service air line will activate.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line controls the emergency brakes on a combination vehicle. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: What is the number one cause of death and injury in a work zone?
questions.explanation: Speeding is the leading cause of death and injury in work zones. Use extra caution when driving near workers in a work zone.

questions.question: Hazardous materials laws are controlled by:
questions.explanation: Because of the risks presented by the nature of the materials, government on federal, state, and local levels may impose regulations on the transportation of hazardous materials.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a shipping paper?
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: A person driving with an open window in cold weather may be:
questions.answerB: A person who is dressed inappropriately.
questions.answerC: A person who likes fresh air.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they have their windows rolled down in cold weather.

questions.question: If you identify hazardous materials leaking while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving to find a phone booth and call the National Response Center.
questions.answerC: Leave the area to find help.
questions.explanation: If you discover that a cargo of hazardous materials is leaking from your vehicle, you should park the vehicle as soon as possible. The longer you continue driving, the longer the trail of contamination becomes. While this creates potential danger and harm to others, it also increases clean-up expenses.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerB: Should be repaired, but not immediately.
questions.explanation: The suspension system performs the vital functions of holding up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in the suspension are therefore extremely dangerous.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of distraction?
questions.explanation: Distractions that can affect safe driving can be classified as physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as talking with passenger), or both (such as talking on a hand-held phone).

questions.question: On packages that are not large enough to hold a HazMat label, materials should be labeled:
questions.answerC: With a piece of orange tape.
questions.explanation: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to display the proper label, the label may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: While driving, shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: While hazardous materials are being transported, shipping papers should either be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be clearly visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Keeping cargo centered on a rig can:
questions.explanation: A rollover is more likely if cargo is unevenly loaded in a rig. To help prevent a dangerous rollover, it is important to keep a load as centered on the rig as possible.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.answerA: Loosen your grip on the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Check your tires after coming to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: In the event of tire failure, hold the steering wheel firmly. Stay off the brakes and let the vehicle slow down on its own. Once the vehicle has slowed considerably, you should brake very gently, pull off the road, and stop. Check your tires after coming to a complete stop.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, you can tell that your vehicle's ABS is not working if:
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the right side of the trailer flashes three times.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights flash and then turn off.
questions.explanation: When turning on your vehicle's engine, the lights on the dash should come on and then turn off. If the ABS malfunction light stays on, the system is not working properly. In the case of a truck with a trailer, if the yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on once the engine has been started, the system is not working properly.

questions.question: When loading a tank divided by bulkheads into smaller tanks, the load should be:
questions.explanation: Keep weight distribution in mind when loading cargo into a trailer or tank. When loading a tank that is divided by bulkheads into multiple smaller tanks, you should not place too much weight in the front or rear of the tank.

questions.question: Which of the following is a sign of a potentially drunk driver?
questions.answerA: They are staying in their traffic lane.
questions.answerB: They are driving a consistent speed.
questions.answerC: They are stopping without a reason.
questions.answerD: They have alcohol-related bumper stickers on their vehicle.
questions.explanation: Warning signs that a driver may be impaired include that they are having trouble staying in their lane, they are having trouble maintaining an appropriate driving speed, or they are stopping without a clear reason.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.explanation: While testing for a CDL, an applicant will be required to go through a full vehicle inspection. The vehicle inspection test will include an engine oil level check.

questions.question: Which of the following indicates drowsy driving?
questions.answerA: Eyes going out of focus by themselves
questions.answerB: Having trouble keeping your head up
questions.explanation: Indicators of drowsiness while driving include your eyes closing or going out of focus by themselves, having trouble keeping your head up, and drifting between lanes.

questions.question: When exiting your vehicle, you:
questions.answerA: Must maintain four points of contact with the vehicle.
questions.answerB: May turn to face the road before your exit is complete.
questions.answerC: Must be facing away from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: When driving, the steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held with both hands on opposite sides of the wheel.
questions.answerC: Held with both hands at the bottom of the wheel.
questions.answerD: Held with both hands at the top of the wheel.
questions.explanation: Hold the steering wheel firmly with both hands, placing them on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: If one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing when a vehicle is inspected:
questions.answerA: The vehicle’s driver will be allowed to drive, but only at reduced speeds.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be put out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will be fine to drive since most of the spring is in place.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's suspension, you should look for broken or missing leaves in the leaf springs. Any defect of this kind is dangerous. If one-fourth or more of the leaves are missing from any leaf spring, the vehicle must be put out-of-service.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.answerD: One minute of hitting the brakes.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: A cargo van is:
questions.answerA: Usually the same height with or without a load.
questions.answerB: Usually taller with a heavy load than with a light load.
questions.answerC: Usually shorter with a heavy load than with a light load.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle loses its ABS?
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. If ABS is not working, the basic braking functions on a vehicle will still remain, so the driver can continue to drive and brake normally.

questions.question: A person driving with an open window in cold weather may be:
questions.answerB: A person who is dressed inappropriately.
questions.answerC: A person who likes fresh air.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they have their windows rolled down in cold weather.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. This makes the road look as if it is merely wet.

questions.question: On a bus, carry-on baggage should be stored:
questions.answerA: In a manner that allows riders to exit through any window or door in an emergency.
questions.answerB: In the aisle near the front of the bus.
questions.explanation: The aisles and stairwells of a bus should always be kept clear. Luggage and freight must be placed in a location that allows passengers to exit through any window or door in the event of an emergency.

questions.question: If your truck or trailer catches fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Park in a congested area near trees.
questions.explanation: If there is a fire in your vehicle, the first thing you need to do is leave the road and stop. Park in an open area away from anything that could catch fire, such as plants or other vehicles. Do not pull into a service station.

questions.question: When near a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: You should expect to hear every approaching train.
questions.answerB: You may not hear a train, even if one is approaching.
questions.answerC: You will hear two short blasts of a train's horn if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: You should never assume that you will hear an approaching train. The train operator may fail to sound the horn, or the use of a train's horn may be prohibited in a specific area. Even if the train does sound its horn, noise from inside your own vehicle may prevent you from hearing the train until it is dangerously close.

questions.question: In low temperatures, bridges usually freeze:
questions.answerA: After other parts of the roadway.
questions.answerB: Before other parts of the roadway.
questions.answerC: At the same time as other parts of the roadway.
